awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of Mass Spectrometer-Coupled Thermogravimetric Analyzer System
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded by the Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) and Chemical Instrumentation (CRIF) programs.  Professor Jeremy Feldblyum from SUNY at Albany and colleagues John Welch, Rabi Musah, Evgeny Dikarev and Marina Petrukhina have acquired a thermal gravimetric analysis system equipped with a mass spectrometer (TGA-MS).  This instrument measures the weight of a sample as it is heated.  As vapors evolve, the samples are analyzed by a mass spectrometer to determine the mass and chemical composition of the vapors emitted.  This data provides information on the identity of the sample itself and its composition (if a mixture).  The vapors may be decomposition products providing information on the thermal stability of the sample.   TGA-MS is a powerful tool in analyzing materials.  The research may impact many areas, including organic and inorganic chemistry and polymer chemistry.  One example involves the synthesis of materials which can be used to separate high-value organic compounds in hydrocarbon fuels which are difficult to separate by distillation.  In another project, energy storage materials are being tested.  The thermal decomposition of novel polymers used in photolithography is also being investigated.  Instrumentation usage by local research institutions, including universities and colleges, commercial companies and government institutions (eg. the NY State Crime Laboratory) is encouraged. The instrument provides training opportunities for students at both the undergraduate and graduate levels in research and laboratory instruction. 

The acquisition of this thermogravimetric analyzer enhances the research and education of undergraduate and graduate students at SUNY at Albany and surrounding institutions. Heterometallic molecular precursors for the preparation of energy-related materials are under investigation.   Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are being tested for separating high-value organic compounds.  Storage materials such as for hydrogen capture are being synthesized and tested.  The decomposition mechanism of polymers useful in photolithography is followed in thermal heating studies.  Water desorption studies from RNA strands/fibers is assessed to understand thermal robustness and relative heats of adsorption.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

por.por_cntn:
This award was provided by the National Science Foundation to fund the purchase of a Mass Spectrometer-Coupled Thermogravimetric Analyzer system (TGA-MS) by The University at Albany, SUNY. TGA-MS is a highly sensitive technique that can be used to measure precise changes in sample mass as a function of temperature. The purchased system can heat samples up to 1200 °C – sufficient for the decomposition of organic and metal-organic compounds, and hot enough to study the oxidation of many metals and alloys. Furthermore, the chemical byproducts of decomposition can be identified, leading to a better understanding of the composition of chemicals and materials analyzed with the instrument, as well as a detailed view into the factors that drive degradation. This system was purchased to spur innovation in chemistry and materials research, to foster collaborations with local academic institutions and companies, and to educate students and regional scientists in to fully understand and utilize the instruments’ advanced capabilities.

            The instrument supported multiple projects throughout the course of the award period. A new class of polymers combining solubility (which allows forming into films and membranes), semiconductivity (which allows the conductivity of the polymer to be modulated), and porosity (which enables the polymer to selectively “soak up” large amounts of chemicals) was studied. The TGA-MS showed that the thermal stability of these polymers was sensitive to subtle changes in polymer design: the chemical motifs that make the polymer soluble also play an important role in the temperature at which the polymer degrades. A specific chemical reaction pathway was identified showing how one of these motifs drives degradation. A small modification to this motif to prevent this degradation pathway substantially improved the polymer’s thermal stability. In a separate project, the TGA-MS was used to study the thermal degradation of metal-organic molecules designed to produce battery materials after decomposition. These metal-containing molecules are constructed from metal elements that are used in battery cathodes; the organic parts of these molecules keep the desired elements together at the atomic scale and are also meant to evaporate, leaving little residue behind, at high temperatures. The TGA-MS was used to study the precise temperatures at which these metal-organic molecules decompose, showing exactly how different organic components influence decomposition temperature. Furthermore, the instrument was used to determine the extent to which these organic components are able to leave from the sample and thus efficiently form the desired battery material.

            The purchase of the TGA-MS system fostered several collaborations with academic and commercial institutions. The instrument was used by researchers at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute (RPI) to better understand the chemistry of polymers that degrade at relatively low temperature – these polymers might replace polystyrene is more easily recycled plastics. Researchers at the neighboring SUNY Polytechnic examined proprietary materials that show promise for next-generation semiconductor manufacturing. Staff researchers at Momentive Performance Materials examined several proprietary samples using the TGA-MS. Finally, as of this writing, scientists at Edwards Vacuum plan to use the TGA-MS to examine the behavior of chemicals that can damage the vacuum pumps used in semiconductor manufacturing processes. TGA-MS can lend insight into the temperatures at which these chemicals might become harmful contaminants, and may also provide information on the byproducts of their degradation (which may also be deleterious towards semiconductor fabrication).

            The TGA-MS system has played an important role on the education of undergraduate and graduate students alike. Students in no fewer than six research laboratories received training on the instrument; two have graduated and are working in the semiconductor and pharmaceutical industries. Furthermore, the TGA-MS will play a central role in a new, recently-approved laboratory course in polymer chemistry at SUNY Albany.


Last Modified: 12/15/2022
Modified by: Jeremy I Feldblyum
